Award.AwardTitle: Native Point Defects, Electronically Active Impurities, and Plasmonics at ZnO Interfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description: This research project examines the use of native point defects, degenerate doping, and nanostructures to advance the understanding of contact rectification, photon-plasmon coupling, and nanocontacts at ZnO interfaces. It builds on existing capabilities to identify the electrical activity of native point defects on a nanometer scale using optical and electronic techniques, to measure their effect on carrier densities and atomic dopant concentrations quantitatively, and to controllably introduce or suppress these native point defects using nanoscale surface science techniques. Native point defects have a major effect on ZnO Schottky barrier heights, and their interplay with dopant impurities influence plasmonic-resonance wavelengths in ZnO. Because ZnO exhibits a wide range of contact rectification with metals, it can serve to test the relative contributions of thermionic, tunneling, and hopping transport through ZnO-metal interfaces on both a macroscopic and nanometer scale, and the balance of physical mechanisms can be used to understand barriers to charge transport for a wide range of compound semiconductor junctions. The carrier densities influenced by native point defects can in turn alter the dielectric response of ZnO and thus the plasmon-resonance frequency used to couple light waves to ultrahigh frequency electronics. This project employs a combination of growth, plasma processing, and atomic indiffusion to control near-interface doping and native point defects on a nanometer scale for both barrier rectification and plasmonic coupling.

Non-technical Description: Semiconductor defects are imperfections such as missing atoms or impurities in otherwise perfect semiconductor crystals. They can be electrically-active, altering the amount of electrical charge free to travel inside transistors, lasers, and other electronic devices. They can also serve as shortcuts for charge to move through electronic barriers usually designed to block such charge movement for transistor switching, charge storage, or carrier confined light emission. The influence of these defects in charge movement across ZnO interfaces provides a test bed to understand and control other semiconductors, an issue starting when these materials were first used for electronics. Their control can enable high carrier densities for transparent electronics such as heads-up displays and smart windows, high positive charge densities for lasers, and control of the coupling between light waves and electronic circuits at wavelengths important for telecommunications. The project provides training of graduate students, undergraduates, and high school women in both basic scientific laboratory techniques and advanced micro- and optoelectronic concepts. Students interact directly with international collaborators at the University of Oslo, Sweden, Aalto University, Finland, and CNRS / CRHEA, France. The project involves and supports women at the high school through the Columbus School for Girls' summer research internship program, building on NSF core funding with support from several Ohio State University institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project has been to understand how imperfections such as missing atoms in the crystalline lattice structure of semiconductors together with extremely high concentrations of intentionally added electrons influence how electricity passes through metal contacts into these semiconductors and how light can couple to the semiconductor’s electrons. This knowledge can help our ability to create advanced electronic devices that convert optical communications into digital electronics. Our project used our optical and electronic measurement techniques with nanometer scale precision to identify how these imperfections, termed defects, contribute positive or negative charge to the semiconductor, how they affect these speed with which charge moves inside the semiconductor, and how they can be suppressed by atomic layer-scale methods.  Much of this work focused on semiconductor structures on the microscopic scale, both at the intimate metal-semiconductor interface and at metal interfaces with semiconductor nanostructures. We demonstrated how to create metal contacts to nanostructures of zinc oxide, an important semiconductor with many desirable optical, electronic, and environmentally friendly properties, using common electron microscope techniques.   We showed how to use energetic ion and electron beams to remove defects and change interface charge transport, e.g., how charges move into and out of the semiconductor. We produced microscopic maps to show how these defects moved under applied electric fields, which suggests new ways to pull defects out of semiconductors, at least at the nanoscale. We developed a new theoretical method that uses light reflectance and transmission measurements to calculate the real and imaginary parts of the index of refraction, a parameter that is central to determining optical properties of electronic materials and how defects and impurities affect them. We showed how missing zinc atoms and copper atoms on these vacant sites changed how strongly a metal contact to zinc oxide could block or pass current, depending on how these defects were distributed spatially on a nanometer scale. We showed for the first time how a zinc oxide layer with a high concentration of electrons can produce a highly conducting layer at the interface with the same semiconductor but with a much lower concentration. This single semiconductor-semiconductor junction holds promise for development into a high frequency communications transistor due to its structural simplicity. We used the nanometer-scale depth dependence of our luminescence spectroscopy to reveal the physical nature of major defects in beta-gallium oxide, a semiconductor that can withstand the extremely high voltages used for high speed, high power electronics. Using the optical identification of these defects, researchers can now monitor their presence during crystal growth and chemical processing, improving methods to remove defects from this semiconductor. With the near-nanometer depth sensitivity of our electronic and optical techniques, we identified and guided atomic layer growth to remove defects inside the leading complex oxide heterojunction. With these defects removed, we discovered the presence of a highly mobile two-dimensional, positively charged conducting layer in epitaxially grown SrTiO3/LaAlO3/SrTiO3 heterostructures, two otherwise insulating materials. Up to now, only negatively charged channel layers have been achieved in this field. The coexistence of a 2DEG and a 2DHG in a single oxide heterostructure provides a platform for the exciting physics of confined electron–hole systems and for developing applications. Over the past three years, we published more than thirty peer-reviewed journal articles and one book, trained four graduate students, two of whom graduated with Ph.D.’s and two with M.S. degrees. In addition, we trained several undergraduates who graduated with senior theses and went on to graduate school. We also provided summer research internships to twelve high school women, all of whom have gone on to major in STEM fields in college.
